Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Smart Automation of Garden Monitoring and Maintenance
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to make growing produce more convenient and accessible to a new generation of gardeners while enabling student engagement and professional development of the team. The project aims to reconnect people with the way that food is grown in a way that helps them and the planet. This connection is critical to helping people make healthier food choices. By enabling people to grow their own food, we also connect them with the reality of seasons and enable them to make choices that are better for the environment. The project will also provide a platform for student engagement with entrepreneurship, product development, and engineering design. Students are a part of and have shaped smart garden automation from the beginning, and the team plans to continue to work with academic institutions to maintain this relationship. Finally, the NSF I-Corps program will help this team develop the skills necessary to create value from ideas. This learning curve will be critical as the team moves forward on this project, and will better prepare them to be both leaders and mentors for others in the future.

This I-Corps project is about a smart gardening system that lets gardeners grow more plants with less work. By harnessing recent technical advancements in low-power wireless communication, moisture sensors, and networked device protocols, the system makes gardening more convenient and accessible. When paired with a smart phone or web interface, this system has the potential to better enable a generation of gardeners and lead to healthier people, more efficient water usage and storm-water management, and a lower average carbon footprint for a given person's diet. The intellectual merit in this project is demonstrated by the fact that there are no existing systems on the market that can do all of things that this project's invention is set to do. The NSF I-Corps program will help the project team recognize the market segments for any potential commercial product.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project outcomes for this NSF I-Corps proposal revolve around refining the business model and finding product-market fit for a smart irrigation system. It was initially positioned for home gardeners, but from over 200 interviews to date we've explored many target markets with the help of NSF support. The best product-market fit to date has been with green roof installers and living wall industry, with landscape design/build firms coming after that.  

The intellectual merit involved the successful development of the hardware and software needed to sell the system to early adopters. This involved but hardware development and prototyping, printed circuit board design, firmware development, mobile app development, and investigations of platforms that could handle different radio frequencies, pair devices easily, and enable notifications. It's an internet of things (IOT) project that builds on available platforms for a novel application. 

Although the value propositions to the customers do not always include things like saving water, efficient use of resources (water, time, energy) is certainly a broader impact of system implementation. Customers typically care the most about remote access to valves and moisture data, notifications if there is something off in the system, and optimizing performance and aesthetics of their installations. The broader impacts are an added bonus to the customers and a great differentiator for them.
